message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Excessive intake of vitamin E can result in bleeding and hemorrhage, as it can interfere with blood clotting. None of the other options are side effects of excessive vitamin E intake.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Large doses of vitamin E can increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage, which the patient should be concerned about if he continues his supplementation. Night blindness is a side effect of vitamin A deficiency, peripheral neuropathy can be caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, and deep venous thrombosis is not associated with vitamin E supplementation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitamin E is a fat-soluble nutrient that can increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage in high doses, which should be a concern for the patient if he continues his supplementation. Night blindness is a symptom of vitamin A deficiency, deep venous thrombosis is related to blood clotting disorders, and peripheral neuropathy is associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, which are not related to vitamin E supplementation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Large doses of vitamin E can increase the risk of bleeding or hemorrhage, as vitamin E can interfere with blood clotting. Night blindness is related to vitamin A deficiency, deep venous thrombosis is related to factors such as immobility and hypercoagulable states, and peripheral neuropathy is related to vitamin B12 deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitamin E supplementation can increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage, especially if taken in large doses. This can be a concern for the patient if he continues his regimen without consulting a healthcare professional. None of the other options listed are associated with vitamin E supplementation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Large doses of vitamin E can cause hemorrhage, specifically by interfering with vitamin K. Night blindness is a symptom of vitamin A deficiency. Deep venous thrombosis is not a common side effect of vitamin E supplementation. Peripheral neuropathy is a potential side effect of vitamin B6 toxicity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitamin E has anticoagulant properties and can increase the risk of hemorrhage, especially when taken in large doses. None of the other options are associated with vitamin E toxicity or overdose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitamin E acts as an anticoagulant, which can increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage. Night blindness is a symptom of vitamin A deficiency, deep venous thrombosis is not a side-effect of vitamin E supplementation, and peripheral neuropathy is associated with certain vitamin deficiencies, but usually not with vitamin E supplementation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only hemorrhage is a possible side effect of high doses of vitamin E. It can interfere with blood clotting, causing bleeding problems. Night blindness is a side effect of vitamin A deficiency. Deep venous thrombosis and peripheral neuropathy are not associated with high doses of vitamin E. It is important for the patient to consult a healthcare professional before starting any supplement regimen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Vitamin E, in large doses, can cause a risk of hemorrhage due to its ability to inhibit platelet aggregation. Night blindness is associated with Vitamin A deficiency, deep venous thrombosis is associated with hormonal treatments and surgeries, and peripheral neuropathy is associated with Vitamin B12 deficiency.
